question: You exit the freeway on a ramp that curves downhill. You should:

options.text: Slow to a safe speed before the curve.
Slow to the posted speed limit for the freeway.
Wait until you have entered the curve to begin braking.

correct: Slow to a safe speed before the curve.
explanation: You should always slow down before entering a curve. You may not be able to see hazards ahead and braking in a curve may cause your vehicle to skid.

question: When parking your vehicle on any hill:

options.text: One of your rear wheels should touch the curb.
Use your parking brake and leave the vehicle in "park."
Your front wheels should be parallel to the road, if there is no curb.

correct: Use your parking brake and leave the vehicle in "park."
explanation: When parking on a hill, you should always leave your vehicle in gear or in the "park" position. If there is no curb, you should turn your front wheels so that the vehicle will roll away from the center of the road if the brakes fail. If there is a curb, the front wheels should be turned toward it (if headed downhill) or away from and gently touching it (if headed uphill).

question: You see pedestrians near the road. You should:

options.text: Sound your horn and maintain your speed.
Speed up to clear the area quickly.
Slow down and pass with caution.

correct: Slow down and pass with caution.
explanation: Watch for any pedestrian who may cross your path. If you see pedestrians near the road where you are driving, slow down and be prepared to stop, if necessary.

question: You must stop at the intersection ahead. Just before the intersection, you have to cross railroad tracks. You should stop before crossing the railroad tracks when:

options.text: There isn't room on the other side for you to completely cross the tracks.
The crossing is located in a city or town with frequent train traffic.
You are transporting two or more children in a passenger vehicle.

correct: There isn't room on the other side for you to completely cross the tracks.
explanation: If you need to stop after crossing railroad tracks, wait until you can completely cross the tracks before proceeding. Make sure your vehicle clears the tracks before you stop.

question: If you parallel park facing downward on a hill:

options.text: Turn your wheels sharply toward the side of the road.
Turn your wheels away from the side of the road.
Keep your wheels straight.

correct: Turn your wheels sharply toward the side of the road.
explanation: When parking downhill, turn your front wheels toward the curb or edge of the road. When parking uphill on a road without a curb, turn your wheels toward the edge of the road. When parking uphill on a road with a curb, you must turn your front wheels away from the curb.

question: If you want to enter the freeway but you don't see a gap in traffic, you should:

options.text: Maintain your speed and force the other drivers to create a gap.
Slow down on the ramp to wait for a gap.
Stop at the end of the ramp to wait for a gap.

correct: Slow down on the ramp to wait for a gap.
explanation: If you want to enter the freeway but do not see a space for your vehicle in traffic, slow down on the ramp to wait for a gap. Do not drive to the end of the ramp and wait for a gap or you will not have enough room to accelerate to the speed of traffic before entering the roadway.

question: You want to make a right turn at the corner. A pedestrian with a guide dog is at the corner ready to cross the street in front of you. Before making your right turn, you should:

options.text: Turn off your engine until the person crosses the street.
Tell the pedestrian when to cross the street.
Wait until the person crosses the street.

correct: Wait until the person crosses the street.
explanation: Pedestrians using guide dogs or white canes (with or without a red tip) must be given the right-of-way at all times.

question: At an uncontrolled intersection where you cannot see cross traffic until you are just about to enter the intersection, the speed limit is:

options.text: 15 mph.
25 mph.
20 mph.

correct: 15 mph.
explanation: The speed limit for a blind intersection is 15 mph. An intersection is considered “blind” if there are no stop signs on any corner and you cannot see for 100 feet in either direction during the last 100 feet before crossing.

question: You should turn on your headlights:

options.text: One half hour after sunset.
When stopped at a railroad crossing.
When parked at a school.

correct: One half hour after sunset.
explanation: Headlights must be used one half hour after sunset until one half hour before sunrise, when windshield wipers are being used due to rain or snow, and in any other situation when visibility is less than 1,000 feet. They should be used when a car is being driven on a small country or mountain road, even in sunny weather.

question: A vehicle suddenly cuts in front of you, creating a hazard. What should you do first?

options.text: Honk and step on the brake firmly.
Take your foot off the gas pedal.
Swerve into the lane next to you.

correct: Take your foot off the gas pedal.
explanation: If a vehicle merges in front of you too closely, take your foot off of the accelerator. This will create space between you and the vehicle ahead without requiring you to slam on your brakes or swerve into another lane.

question: When a pedestrian guided by a dog or carrying a white cane is crossing the street:

options.text: You must always yield the right-of-way.
You must tell them where to cross the street.
You only have to yield the right-of-way if you are at a corner.

correct: You must always yield the right-of-way.
explanation: Blind or partially blind pedestrians may carry a white cane or use the assistance of a guide dog. You must always yield the right-of-way to a pedestrian who is using a guide dog or carrying a white cane.

question: For which of the following traffic lights must you always stop your vehicle?

options.text: Solid red lights, flashing red lights, and blacked out traffic signals.
Solid red lights, red arrows, and flashing yellow lights.
Solid red lights, flashing red lights, and yellow lights.

correct: Solid red lights, flashing red lights, and blacked out traffic signals.
explanation: You must stop at a solid or flashing red light, or at a signal light that is blacked out (not working). A solid yellow light means that the signal is about to turn red and you must stop if you can do so safely; otherwise, proceed cautiously. A flashing yellow light means that you should proceed with caution, but you do not need to stop.

question: To make a right turn at a corner, you:

options.text: May not enter the bicycle lane.
Should only merge into the bicycle lane if you stop before turning.
Must merge into the bicycle lane before turning.

correct: Must merge into the bicycle lane before turning.
explanation: When making a right turn where there is a bicycle lane, you must merge into the bicycle lane no more than 200 feet before the corner and then make the turn. Be sure there are no bicyclists in your path before merging.

question: You must yield to a pedestrian using a white cane or guide dog:

options.text: Only when the guide dog is leading the person across the street.
At all times.
Only if a crossing guard is present.

correct: At all times.
explanation: Pedestrians who use guide dogs or white canes (with or without a red tip) must be given the right-of-way at all times.

question: You are coming to an intersection with a flashing red light. You should:

options.text: Slow down and yield the right-of-way.
Slow down and drive carefully through the intersection.
Come to a complete stop, check the traffic, and go when it is safe to do so.

correct: Come to a complete stop, check the traffic, and go when it is safe to do so.
explanation: A flashing red traffic light means the same thing as a stop sign. You must come to a complete stop, yield to other traffic and pedestrians, and then proceed when it safe to do so.

question: This road sign means:

options.text: Do not enter.
No parking.
No U-turn.

correct: No U-turn.
explanation: This sign prohibits drivers from making a U-turn. You cannot turn around to go in the opposite direction at an intersection where this sign is posted.

question: Placard abuse will result in:

options.text: Placard revocation only.
Only a fine.
Placard revocation, a fine, and/or jail time.

correct: Placard revocation, a fine, and/or jail time.
explanation: Abuse of a disabled placard or plate is a misdemeanor. Placard abuse can result in the loss of special parking privileges, a fine of up to $1,000, and up to six months of jail time.

question: When can you drive in a bike lane?

options.text: During rush hour traffic if there are no bicyclists in the bike lane.
When you are within 200 feet of a cross street where you plan to turn right.
When you want to pass a driver ahead of you who is turning right.

correct: When you are within 200 feet of a cross street where you plan to turn right.
explanation: If there is a bike lane, drive into the bike lane no more than 200 feet before a turn. Watch for bicyclists or motorcyclists who may get between your vehicle and the curb.

question: You want to turn left at an upcoming corner. Yield the right-of-way to:

options.text: Oncoming vehicles also turning left.
All approaching vehicles.
Pedestrians on the sidewalk waiting for a "Walk" signal.

correct: All approaching vehicles.
explanation: When making a left turn, you must yield to pedestrians, bicyclists, or other vehicles moving on their green light.

question: When stopping on snow or ice, drivers who are operating vehicles equipped with an Anti-Lock Braking System (ABS) should:

options.text: Pump the brakes.
Press and hold the brake pedal firmly.
Stay off the brakes and wait for the car to drift to a stop.

correct: Press and hold the brake pedal firmly.
explanation: When driving a vehicle equipped with an Anti-Lock Braking System (ABS), a driver should press the brake pedal firmly when stopping on a snowy or icy surface. The ABS will pump the brakes more rapidly than a driver would be able to.

question: When entering the interstate on a short entrance ramp where there is no acceleration lane, you should:

options.text: Immediately enter the far-right traffic lane on the interstate and speed up to match the flow of traffic.
Use the shoulder of the main road to get up to the speed of traffic.
Speed up and enter the interstate only after you have identified a gap in traffic.

correct: Speed up and enter the interstate only after you have identified a gap in traffic.
explanation: When entering the interstate on a short entrance ramp where there is no acceleration lane, speed up only after you have identified a gap in traffic. In general, you should be stopped while waiting for a gap to appear.

question: You want to park downhill on a two-way road and there is no curb. Which way do you turn your front wheels?

options.text: Straight ahead
Right, toward the side of the road
Left, toward the center of the road

correct: Right, toward the side of the road
explanation: When parking facing downhill on a road with or without a curb, or when facing uphill on a road without a curb, turn your front wheels toward the edge of the road so your vehicle will roll away from traffic if the brakes fail. However, when parking uphill on a road with a curb, turn your wheels toward the center of the road so the vehicle will roll into the curb if the brakes fail.

question: You must notify the DMV within five days if you:

options.text: Are cited for a traffic violation.
Sell or transfer your vehicle.
Paint your vehicle a different color.

correct: Sell or transfer your vehicle.
explanation: You are required by law to contact the DMV within five calendar days from the date you sell or transfer the title of a vehicle to another owner. They must be notified of every title transfer.

question: If you are involved in a traffic accident in California, you must file a report of the accident with the DMV when:

options.text: The collision causes $1,000 in damage.
You plan on being out of the state for more than 30 days.
You refinance the remaining balance of your vehicle loan.

correct: The collision causes $1,000 in damage.
explanation: If a collision results in death, any minor or major injury, or more than $1,000 in damage to anyone's property, each driver involved must file a report with the DMV within 10 days. In some cases, the driver's insurance agent, broker, or legal representative may file the report to represent the driver.

question: A flashing red traffic light at an intersection means:

options.text: The same thing as a yield sign.
The light is about to turn green.
The same thing as a stop sign.

correct: The same thing as a stop sign.
explanation: A flashing red light at an intersection means drivers are required to come to a complete stop, yield to traffic and pedestrians, and proceed when the way is clear. The same is true at a stop sign.

question: Which of these vehicles must always stop before crossing railroad tracks?

options.text: Tank trucks with hazardous materials placards.
Motor homes or pickup trucks towing a boat trailer.
Sport utility vehicles carrying four or more persons.

correct: Tank trucks with hazardous materials placards.
explanation: A diamond-shaped sign on a truck means that the load on the truck is potentially dangerous (containing gas, explosives, etc.). Vehicles displaying these signs are required to stop before crossing railroad tracks.

question: When a bicyclist is making a left turn:

options.text: They may use the left lane.
They may cut through all lanes.
They may wait on the side of the road.

correct: They may use the left lane.
explanation: You should expect to see bicyclists driving with traffic on the road. You should not be surprised to see a bicyclist using the left lane when turning.

question: You may cross double yellow lines to pass another vehicle if the:

options.text: Vehicle in front of you moves to the right to let you pass.
Yellow line next to your side of the road is broken.
Yellow line next to the opposite side of the road is broken.

correct: Yellow line next to your side of the road is broken.
explanation: A broken yellow line in the center of the road indicates that traffic next to the broken yellow line may pass, if it is safe to do so.

question: When you are merging onto the freeway, you should be driving:

options.text: At or near the speed of traffic on the freeway.
Five to 10 mph slower than the speed of traffic on the freeway.
The posted speed limit for freeway traffic.

correct: At or near the speed of traffic on the freeway.
explanation: When merging onto a freeway, you should enter at or near the speed of traffic.

question: If there is no crosswalk and you see a pedestrian crossing your lane, you should:

options.text: Make sure the pedestrian can see you before proceeding.
Cautiously drive around the pedestrian.
Stop and let the pedestrian finish crossing.

correct: Stop and let the pedestrian finish crossing.
explanation: Drivers must always yield the right-of-way to pedestrians in the roadway, even if there is not a marked crosswalk.

question: When approaching an intersection with a flashing red light, you must:

options.text: Come to a complete stop, yield to oncoming traffic and pedestrians, then proceed.
Reduce your speed and proceed with caution.
Come to a complete stop and remain stopped as long as the light is red.

correct: Come to a complete stop, yield to oncoming traffic and pedestrians, then proceed.
explanation: A flashing red traffic light means the same thing as a stop sign. When arriving at an intersection with a flashing red light, you must come to a full stop and proceed when it is safe to do so.

question: While driving at night, a vehicle coming toward you has its high beams on, making it hard for you to see the road ahead. You should:

options.text: Look ahead toward the left edge of your lane.
Look ahead toward the right edge of your lane.
Look straight ahead in your lane.

correct: Look ahead toward the right edge of your lane.
explanation: If an oncoming driver fails to dim their high beams, you should avoid looking directly at the headlights. Instead, look toward the right edge of your lane and watch the oncoming vehicle out of the corner of your eye.

question: Before stopping your vehicle at a traffic signal or sign, you should:

options.text: Press down hard on the accelerator.
Check your mirrors for surrounding traffic.
Set the parking brake.

correct: Check your mirrors for surrounding traffic.
explanation: When stopping your vehicle on the roadway, first check your mirrors for traffic. Be aware of surrounding drivers as you release the accelerator and allow your vehicle to slow. Move your foot to the brake pedal and press with steady pressure for a smooth stop.

question: You hit a parked vehicle and can't find the owner. What must you do?

options.text: Call your insurance company when you get home.
Wait for the owner to return.
Leave a note with your name and address on the parked vehicle.

correct: Leave a note with your name and address on the parked vehicle.
explanation: If you hit a parked vehicle or other property, you must leave a note with your name, phone number, and address securely attached to the vehicle or property that you hit.

question: What is the only medically proven method of removing alcohol or other drug combinations from your system?

options.text: Breathe in some fresh air.
Give your body time.
Drink coffee.

correct: Give your body time.
explanation: Alcohol takes effect quickly and is slow to leave your system. Cold showers, black coffee, and exercise will do nothing to reduce a person's blood alcohol content (BAC). The only way to lower your BAC is to wait.

question: If the roadway is wet or icy, you should:

options.text: Reduce your speed.
Drive at the posted speed.
Speed up.

correct: Reduce your speed.
explanation: Because your tires will not grip the road under wet, snowy, or icy conditions as well as they will under dry conditions, you should slow down if the roadway is wet or icy.

question: Stopping distances and the severity of collisions:

options.text: Decrease as a vehicle's speed increases.
Are not affected by a vehicle's speed.
Increase as a vehicle's speed increases.

correct: Increase as a vehicle's speed increases.
explanation: Excessive vehicle speed can have disastrous effects. As a vehicle's speed increases, the potential impact of a collision also increases, elevating the possibility of serious injury and death. Increase your following distance as your speed increases to ensure that you will be able to stop safely if needed.

question: This sign means:

options.text: Four-lane traffic ahead.
Divided highway ahead.
Two-way traffic ahead.

correct: Two-way traffic ahead.
explanation: Warning signs are usually yellow with black markings. They alert you to conditions that are immediately ahead. This sign warns that you are leaving a separated one-way highway and will soon be driving on a two-way highway.

question: As you approach an intersection with a flashing yellow light:

options.text: Stop before crossing the intersection.
Slow down and proceed with caution.
Wait for a green light before proceeding.

correct: Slow down and proceed with caution.
explanation: A flashing yellow light means that you should slow down, check for cross traffic, and proceed with caution.

question: When you see a flashing yellow light at an intersection, you should:

options.text: Yield to all traffic before crossing the intersection.
Stop, then enter the intersection when it is safe to do so.
Slow down and cross the intersection carefully.

correct: Slow down and cross the intersection carefully.
explanation: A flashing yellow light at an intersection indicates that drivers should slow to a safe and reasonable speed and proceed with caution.

question: After you have passed a vehicle moving in the same direction, it is safe to move back into the right lane:

options.text: After about three seconds.
When you can no longer see the passed vehicle over your right shoulder.
When you can see the entire front of the passed vehicle in your rearview mirror.

correct: When you can see the entire front of the passed vehicle in your rearview mirror.
explanation: When passing, you should not return to your original lane until you can see both headlights of the passed vehicle in your rearview mirror. Always check your blind spots before moving back into your original lane.

question: A sign with this shape means:

options.text: No passing zone.
Right turn permitted on red.
Yield right-of-way.

correct: No passing zone.
explanation: A pennant-shaped sign marks the beginning of a no passing zone.

question: If a road is slippery, maintain a following distance that is:

options.text: No different than normal.
Farther from the car ahead than normal.
Closer to the car ahead than normal.

correct: Farther from the car ahead than normal.
explanation: You need a longer distance to stop your vehicle on a slippery road than you do on a dry road. Maintain an increased following distance when driving on slippery roads.

question: You are merging onto an interstate highway. You should:

options.text: Select a safe gap and merge into the lane of traffic.
Merge across two lanes at once.
Always stop before entering the highway.

correct: Select a safe gap and merge into the lane of traffic.
explanation: Anytime you want to merge with other drivers, you need to find a gap large enough for you to safely enter into the flow of traffic. You should not stop on the entrance ramp to an interstate highway unless there are no gaps into which you may safely merge.

question: To be able to turn quickly, your hands must be:

options.text: On opposite sides of the steering wheel.
Next to each other on the top of the steering wheel.
On the top and bottom of the steering wheel.

correct: On opposite sides of the steering wheel.
explanation: Both hands should be placed on opposite sides of the steering wheel. This position is comfortable and promotes safe turning on high-speed roadways.

question: Excessive speed:

options.text: Does not increase the chance of a crash.
Increases your ability to react to a hazard.
Often leads to high-risk decision-making.

correct: Often leads to high-risk decision-making.
explanation: Excessive speed is one of the most common contributing factors to vehicle crashes. Excessive speed does not save time and often leads to high-risk decision-making.
